revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[File:george-baker-bridget-doyly-carte.jpg|right|thumb|300px|With [[George Baker (baritone)|George Baker]] at a Gilbert and Sullivan Society celebration in 1964]] '''Dame Bridget Cicely D'Oyly Carte''', [[Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire|DBE]] (25 March 1908 – 2 May 1985), was the granddaughter of impresario [[Richard D'Oyly Carte]] and the only daughter of [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]]. She was head of the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]] from 1948 until 1982. Though as a child she was not enthusiastic about [[Gilbert and Sullivan]], after her father's death in 1948, Bridget D'Oyly Carte inherited the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, which performed and controlled the copyrights to the joint works of [[W. S. Gilbert]] and [[Arthur Sullivan]], as well as all of her family's business interests. She had begun to assist her father in managing the [[Savoy Hotel]] in 1933, also undertaking child welfare work. She hired [[Frederic Lloyd]] as general manager of the opera company in 1951 and moved to keep the [[Savoy opera]]s fresh, marketing them as a bridge between popular and classical music. After the copyrights to the Gilbert and Sullivan works expired in 1961, she transferred the opera company to a charitable trust that she headed. Mounting losses, and the refusal of the Arts Council to provide a grant, forced the closure of the company in 1982, although the company re-formed after Carte's death and mounted several productions up to 2003. In 1972, Carte founded the D'Oyly Carte Charitable Trust to support charitable causes in the fields of the arts, medical welfare and the environment. She was created a [[Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire|DBE]] in 1975. With no children of her own or surviving siblings, she was the end of her family line. ==Life and career== Bridget Cicely D'Oyly Carte was born at Suffolk Street, [[Pall Mall, London|Pall Mall]], London, and educated in England and abroad. Her father was [[Rupert D'Oyly Carte]], and her mother was the former Lady Dorothy Milner Gathorne-Hardy (1889–1977), the youngest daughter of the [[John Stewart Gathorne-Hardy, 2nd Earl of Cranbrook|2nd Earl of Cranbrook]].Obituary notice, ''[[The Times]]'', 3 May 1985, p. 11 Her grandfather was [[Richard D'Oyly Carte]], who founded the [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company]].D'Oyly "was a forename (not part of a double surname)". Jacobs, Arthur. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/32311, "Carte, Richard D'Oyly (1844–1901)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, September 2004, accessed 12 September 2008, {{doi|10.1093/ref:odnb/32311}}. The name comes from her grandfather's great grandmother, Elizabeth D'Oyly, who was a descendant of Peregrine D'Oyly of Overbury Hall in [[Layham]], Suffolk (c. 1625–1667). [[File:Savoy Hotel, London.jpg|left|thumb|upright|The [[Savoy Hotel]]]] In 1926, when she was only 18, she married her first cousin, John David Gathorne-Hardy, the fourth [[Earl of Cranbrook]] (1900–1978),Both were grandchildren of [[John Stewart Gathorne-Hardy, 2nd Earl of Cranbrook]]. an explorer and naturalist. As a result of her marriage, Carte was styled as Countess of Cranbrook, and her married name was Gathorne-Hardy.Lundy, Darryl, ed. [http://thepeerage.com/p3563.htm#i35621 "Bridget Cicely Carte"], ThePeerage.com, 28 September 2010. They soon separated and finally divorced in 1931; she relinquished her title and resumed her maiden name by [[deed poll]] in 1932, also dropping the name Cicely, which she disliked.[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U163678 "D'Oyly Carte, Dame Bridget"], ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black, 1920–2008; online edition @ ukwhoswho.com, Oxford University Press, December 2007, accessed 30 March 2011 {{subscription}} She then resumed her education at [[Dartington Hall]] in Devon from 1931 to 1933, a school with a long musical tradition, taking courses in dance, teacher training, art and design. There she met designer [[Peter Goffin]] who became a long-time friend.Taylor, C. M. P. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/31046 "Carte, Dame Bridget Cicely D'Oyly (1908–1985)"], ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'' (2004), Oxford University Press, accessed 20 June 2009. {{subscription}} The accidental death of her only brother, Michael (1911–1932), made Carte the heir to her father's hotel and theatre interests. As a child, however, she had been reluctant to assume the family legacy. She later told ''The Gramophone'' magazine: "At home, you know, we weren't allowed to ''hum'' Gilbert and Sullivan; in fact we were fined for it, because it annoyed my father. We were allowed to sing it properly, but my brother and I couldn't – in my family the fact that I wasn't Mozart at about three years old was thought of as rather disappointing. So I went through a phase when I was very anti-Gilbert and Sullivan; I became rather a highbrow, and my father thought I was a bit of a snake-in-the-grass because of it.""Wimbush, Roger. [http://www.gramophone.net/Issue/Page/March%201975/33/838552 "Here and There"], ''[[Gramophone (magazine)|The Gramophone]]'', March 1975, pp. 1630–33 (p. 33 in online version), accessed 22 February 2011 From 1933 to 1939, Carte was an assistant to her father at the [[Savoy Hotel]], taking responsibility for furnishing and interior decoration, for which she had training and aptitude. Upon the outbreak of the [[Second World War]], however, she undertook child welfare work and continued with it until her father's death in 1948. The family home was [[Coleton Fishacre]], a house that her parents had built in [[Devon]] between [[Paignton]] and [[Kingswear]] in 1925. The house is still known for its design features and garden with exotic tropical plants.''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'', 25 October 2007, pp. 78–80 After her parents' divorce in 1941, Bridget D'Oyly Carte took over the house, which her father, who lived in London, would visit for long weekends. Shortly after her father's death, she sold Coleton Fishacre, and it is now owned by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]].[http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-coletonfishacrehouseandgarden "Coleton Fishacre"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091217084145/http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-coletonfishacrehouseandgarden# |date=17 December 2009 }}, National Trust, accessed 30 March 2011 In 1949 she bought [[Shrubs Wood]], Chalfont St Giles, [[Buckinghamshire]], designed by the architects [[Erich Mendelsohn]] and [[Serge Chermayeff]]. Here she pursued her love of gardening and gave summer parties for disadvantaged or disabled children. In 1953, Carte was a member of the committee overseeing the decorations for the Coronation Ball at the [[Savoy Hotel]] in honour of the coronation of [[Queen Elizabeth II]].''The Times'', 15 November 1952, p. 10 ===Managing the family interests=== When her father died in 1948, she inherited all his interests including the Savoy Hotel group and [[D'Oyly Carte Opera Company|the family's opera company]], which presented the [[Savoy Operas]] from 1875 to 1982. She did not succeed Rupert D'Oyly Carte as chairman of the Savoy Hotel group, in which she retained a large shareholding, but she became an active director. She moved into a suite in the Savoy Hotel and resumed control of the furnishing and decoration departments. When the Savoy Group acquired them, she took interest in the soft-furnishing company, James Edwards, and was chairman of the royal florists, Edward Goodyear Ltd. She became vice-chairman of the Group in 1971 and was its president at the time of her death. At first, Bridget D'Oyly Carte "did not feel qualified to sustain the responsibility" of running the opera company.Mander and Mitchenson, p. 8 Nevertheless, she was determined to prove herself.Lloyd, Frederic. "The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company – How it Works" in ''The Gilbert and Sullivan Journal'', 8/14, May 1964, pp. 220–21 One of her early decisions proved especially unpopular and led to a wave of important defections from the company at the end of the [[Festival of Britain]] season in 1951, most importantly, [[Martyn Green]]. This was the 1949 hiring, as stage director, of [[Eleanor Evans]], Mrs. [[Darrell Fancourt]], known as "Snookie" in the company.Rollins and Witts, p. v Green wrote in 1952:
"I ... told Miss Carte that I thought she was making a great psychological error. During [[Anna Bethell]]'s regime (Mrs. [[Sydney Granville]]), there had been growing signs of discontent and suggestions of favouritism.... But to appoint not only a woman who had for fifteen years worked in the chorus alongside several who were now principals, but the wife of one of the main principals, seemed to me to be a psychological error of the first magnitude. I felt that ... she would, rightly or wrongly, be accused of that very same favouritism. My views made no impression on Miss Carte, but time was to prove that I was right.... Production is done to a plan that takes no consideration of the individual, his personality or his histrionic ability – a stereotyped plan that results in a clockwork performance devoid of spontaneity.Green, pp. 236–37
The historian Tony Joseph wrote: "But Green was not the only member of the Company to leave.... [[Ella Halman]] left too. So did [[Richard Watson (singer)|Richard Watson]] ... Margaret Mitchell ... [[Radley Flynn]] and no fewer than twenty-two other small part players and choristers. It was the largest single exodus of performers in D'Oyly Carte history, and that was why the sense of sadness that hovered over the season was so marked.... August 1951 was the end of an era.Joseph, p. 272 Cynthia Morey, who joined the Company just before the defections, wrote: "I have never found out precisely why this great exodus took place.... We were always under the impression that we should feel honoured to be in the employ of the D’Oyly Carte Opera Company; it was patently obvious that the management held firmly to the policy that nobody is indispensable".Morey, pp. 51–52 Morey noted that Evans had played several roles with the company and commented, "In 1927 she was apparently demoted to the chorus, and there she remained for [fifteen years]. ... I should not have thought these qualifications sufficient for such an important post; to spend all those years as a chorister seems to signify a lack of ambition or achievement. But I suppose a 'Director of Productions' in those days merely needed to know every move and every gesture, and exactly when they occurred, for no departure from the set production was ever permitted."Morey, pp. 81–82 [[Richard Walker (singer)|Richard Walker]], [[Kenneth Sandford]] and others also criticised Evans's temperament and methods. She retired as stage director in 1953, the year that her husband died, but she was engaged to coach new D'Oyly Carte principals in their roles for some years thereafter.Stone, David. [http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/whowaswho/E/EvansEleanor.htm "Eleanor Evans",] ''Who Was Who in the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company'', 24 June 2002; accessed 26 November 2009Watt, John. [http://pinafore.www3.50megs.com/k-sandford-fav.html "The Ones that I Like"], Interview with Sandford, at the Memories of the D'Oyly Carte website, reproduced from ''The Savoyard'', Vol. XI, No. 2, September 1972 Carte made an important move to hire [[Frederic Lloyd]] as general manager in 1951, which position he continued to discharge until the company closed. In running the D'Oyly Carte Opera company she took steps to keep the productions fresh, engaging designers to redesign the costumes and scenery. Her old friend, Peter Goffin, who had previously redesigned ''[[The Yeomen of the Guard]]'' and ''[[Ruddigore]]'' for Rupert D'Oyly Carte, designed a unit set in 1957 to facilitate and reduce the cost of touring. He also produced new settings and costumes for ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'' (1957), ''[[The Mikado]]'' (1958 – settings only, most of the celebrated [[Charles Ricketts]] costumes being retained), ''[[The Gondoliers]]'' (1958), ''[[Trial by Jury]]'' (1959), ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'' (1961), and ''[[Iolanthe]]'' (1961). ''[[Princess Ida]]'' was redesigned by James Wade in 1954. Carte claimed that the most important function of the operas, which in later years she advertised rather as musicals, was "to bridge the generation gap and link serious music to pop."''Sunday Times'', 1 March 1981 She televised and had recordings and films made of some of the operas, engaged [[Malcolm Sargent|Sir Malcolm Sargent]] to conduct performances at the [[Festival of Britain]] season in 1951 at the operas' original London home, the [[Savoy Theatre]], and supported an increasing number of tours of the United States. In 1960 the company's own touring orchestra was formed as a change from the ad hoc recruitment of players at each venue. In 1975 the company produced a centenary season at the Savoy Theatre, in 1977 it gave a royal [[Royal Command Performance]] at [[Windsor Castle]], and in 1979, for the first time, it toured Australia and New Zealand.Wilson and Lloyd, p. 178 ===Later years=== With the approaching end of the D'Oyly Carte monopoly on [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] performances, when the copyright on Gilbert's words expired in 1961, Carte set up the charitable D'Oyly Carte Opera Trust to continue to present the operas. She endowed the trust with the company's scenery, costumes, band parts, recording rights and other assets, together with a cash endowment of £30,000. She formed Bridget D'Oyly Carte Ltd to manage the opera company, with herself as chairman and managing director. Finally, mounting losses, and the refusal of the Arts Council to provide a grant, forced the closure of the company in 1982.Joseph, p. 358 Even after it closed, however, the company's productions and style continued to influence the productions of other companies. [[File:DOCplanter.jpg|left|350px|thumb|Planter in front of the [[Savoy Hotel]] in honour of Carte and her family]] In 1972, she founded the D'Oyly Carte Charitable Trust – entirely separate from the D'Oyly Carte Opera Trust and the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company – supporting charitable causes in the fields of the arts, medical welfare and the environment. In 2001, the trust endowed the D'Oyly Carte Chair in Medicine and the Arts at [[King's College London]] with £2 million.[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/news/news_details.php?news_id=129&year=2001 "First UK Chair in Medicine and the Arts"], King's College, London, 29 March 2001, accessed 30 March 2011 In 1974 she was elected an Honorary Member of the [[Royal Society of Musicians]] of Great Britain, and in 1975 was created a [[Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire|DBE]]. In the 1970s, Carte became the tenant of the semi-ruined [[Barscobe Castle]], [[Balmaclellan]], a small seventeenth-century fortified house in south-west Scotland, which she restored. Always shy, old-fashioned and formal, Carte appreciated simplicity and avoided parties and social events as much as possible. For her ''[[Who's Who (UK)|Who's Who]]'' entry she listed her recreations as, "country living and gardening; reading, theatre and music." ==Death and legacy== A heavy smoker, Carte died of lung cancer in her country home in Shrubs Wood, [[Buckinghamshire]] in 1985, aged 77. Her remains were cremated. She left a fortune of £5,479,888. With no children of her own or surviving siblings, she was the end of her family line. The Savoy hotel group continued under the control of her trustees until 1994.Prynn, Jonathan. [http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23676788-details/Savoy+%27up+for+sale%27+as+Saudi+owner%27s+billions+dwindle/article.do "Savoy 'up for sale' as Saudi owner's billions dwindle"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419060158/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23676788-details/Savoy+'up+for+sale'+as+Saudi+owner's+billions+dwindle/article.do# |date=19 April 2009 }}, 16 April 2009. The group's hotels remained among the most prestigious in London, with the ''[[Evening Standard|London Evening Standard]]'' calling the Savoy "London's most famous hotel" in 2009. A legacy of £1 million from her private fortune enabled a new opera company, using the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company name, to begin operations in 1988. The company secured sponsorship from Sir [[Michael Bishop (businessman)|Michael Bishop]], who eventually became chairman of the Board of Trustees, and [[BMI (airline)|BMI]] British Midland Airways (of which Bishop is chairman).Bradley (2005), pp. 53–69 From 1988 to 2003 the new company produced short seasons each year, mounting productions of the Gilbert and Sullivan operas on tour and in London, as well as operettas by [[Jacques Offenbach]], [[Franz Lehár]] and [[Johann Strauss II]]. The new company did not employ many of the members of the original company and did not follow its performing traditions, even staging some "concept" productions of the operas. Once again, costs outran receipts, public subsidy was denied by the [[Arts Council of Great Britain|English Arts Council]], and the company suspended productions in May 2003. It continues to rent scores. The Gilbert and Sullivan operas, nurtured by the Carte family for over a century, continue to be produced frequently today throughout the English-speaking world and beyond.Bradley, ''passim''[http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/html/websites/index.html List of 200 amateur G&S performing groups] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001125210/http://math.boisestate.edu/gas/html/websites/index.html |date=1 October 2009 }}, The Gilbert and Sullivan Archive, accessed 1 November 2009Lee, Bernard. [http://www.sheffieldtelegraph.co.uk/classical/Gilbert-and-Sullivan-are-still.4348394.jp "Gilbert and Sullivan are still going strong after a century",] ''Sheffield Telegraph'', 1 August 2008 By keeping the Savoy operas popular for so long, the Carte family influenced the course of the [[Cultural influence of Gilbert and Sullivan#Musical theatre and comedy|development of modern musical theatre]] throughout the 20th century.Bargainnier, pp. 120–33Jones, pp. 10–11 ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== *{{cite book|last=Bargainnier|first=Earl F.|year=1989|chapter=W.S. Gilbert and American Musical Theatre|editor=Timothy E. Scheurer (ed.)|title=American Popular Music: Readings from the Popular Press, Vol. 1|location=Bowling Green, OH|publisher=Bowling Green University Popular Press|isbn=0-87972-466-8}} *{{cite book|last= Bradley|first=Ian|year=2005|authorlink=Ian Bradley|title=Oh Joy! Oh Rapture! The Enduring Phenomenon of Gilbert and Sullivan|location=Oxford, UK|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-195-16700-7}} *{{cite book|last=Green|first=Martyn|authorlink=Martyn Green|year=1952|title=Here's a How-de-do|location=New York|publisher=W.W. Norton & Co|oclc=884247}} American Edition(contains information not found in the British edition) *{{cite book|last=Jacobs|first=Arthur|authorlink=Arthur Jacobs|year=1992|edition=second|origyear=1986|title=Arthur Sullivan: A Victorian Musician|location=Portland, Oregon|publisher=Amadeus Press|isbn=0-93134-051-9}} *{{cite book|last=Jones|first=J. Bush|year=2003|title=Our Musicals, Ourselves|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WqQH31qkYNoC&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=Bordman+pinafore&source=bl&ots=-4A-Dm231B&sig=UwT_XytKbxkRXtLo_OV7-_VTlps&hl=en&ei=RPzlSezEBpeUMcSs4I4J&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7#PPA4,M1|location=Lebanon, NH|publisher=Brandeis University Press|isbn=1-58465-311-6}} *{{cite book|last=Joseph|first=Tony|year=1994|title=D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, 1875–1982: An Unofficial History|location=London|publisher=Bunthorne Books|isbn=0-95079-921-1}} *{{Cite book|last=Mander|first=Raymond|author2=Joe Mitchenson|year=1962|title=''A Picture History of Gilbert and Sullivan|location=London|publisher=Vista Books|oclc=317062414}} * {{cite book|last=Morey|first= Cynthia|year= 1998|title=Inclined to Dance and Sing – A D'Oyly Carte journal of the 1950s|location=Chichester|publisher=Prospero Books|isbn=1-90232-003-4}} *{{Cite book|last=Rollins|first=Cyril|author2=R. John Witts|year=1962|title=The D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in Gilbert and Sullivan Operas|location=London|publisher=Michael Joseph, Ltd|oclc=1317843}} (and four supplements published in 1966, 1971, 1976, and 1983) *{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=Robin|author2=[[Frederic Lloyd]]|authorlink=Robin Wilson (mathematician)|year=1984|title=Gilbert & Sullivan – The D'Oyly Carte years|location=London, UK|publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson|isbn=0-297-78505-2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050220163843/http://math.boisestate.edu/GaS/html/carte.html Article on Carte family] *[http://www.doylycarte.org.uk/ D'Oyly Carte Opera Company Website] {{Gilbert and Sullivan}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carte, Bridget D'Oyly}} [[Category:1908 births]] [[Category:1985 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in England]] [[Category:Deaths from lung cancer]] [[Category:People associated with Gilbert and Sullivan]] [[Category:Dames Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:English theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Women theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Opera managers]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{infobox Organization |name = The Chelsea Arts Club |image = Chelsea Arts Club.jpg |image_border = |size = 250px |caption = Chelsea Arts Club clubhouse |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 21 March 1891 | founder = |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[London]], England, United Kingdom |location = 143 Old Church Street, London SW3 6EB |region_served = London |membership = 2,400+ |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.chelseaartsclub.com |remarks = }} '''The Chelsea Arts Club''' is a private members club at '''143 Old Church Street''' in [[Chelsea, London]] with a membership of over 3,800, including artists, sculptors, architects, writers, designers, actors, musicians, photographers, and [[filmmaker]]s. The club was established on 21 March 1891 (in Chelsea), as a rival to the older [[The Arts Club|Arts Club]] in [[Mayfair, London|Mayfair]], on the instigation of the artist [[James McNeill Whistler|James Abbott McNeill Whistler]], who had been a (sometimes controversial) member of the older club.
During its primary season from September–June the Chelsea Arts Club serves as a host for many functions, from instrumental and choral performances to visual arts exhibitions, literary talks, and weekend artist lunches.
Applicants for membership need to be sponsored by two current Members.
The club is located in the former '''Bolton Lodge''', a [[Listed building#England and Wales|Grade II listed]] building on the [[National Heritage List for England]].<ref name=NHLE>{{NHLE|num=1225774|desc=Bolton Lodge|access-date=8 January 2017|mode=cs2}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Chelsea Arts Ball by William Gordon Burn Murdoch.jpg|thumb| ''The Chelsea Art Ball'' by [[William Gordon Burn Murdoch]]]] The Chelsea Arts Club was originally located in rooms at no. 181 [[King's Road]]. In 1902, the club moved to larger premises at no. 143 [[Old Church Street]]. In 1933 the club's premises, which had an acre of garden, were remodeled.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web | url = http://chelseaartsclub.com/home-public/history/ | title = History {{!}} Chelsea Arts Club | website = chelseaartsclub.com | access-date = 2016-02-25 }}</ref> The clubhouse includes a snooker room, bedrooms, dining room, former 'ladies bar' turned private party room, and a garden.
From 1908 to 1958 the club held a series of public [[Fancy dress party|fancy dress balls]] at the [[Albert Hall]], latterly on [[New Year's Eve]], which raised funds for artists' charities.<ref name=":0" /> In 1958 balls were banned from the Albert Hall owing their notoriety for rowdiness, nudity and public homosexuality ([[Sexual Offences Act 1967|illegal before 1967]]).<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://uk.news.yahoo.com/on-this-day--the-chelsea-arts-ball-%E2%80%93-london%E2%80%99s-most-%E2%80%98scandalous--new-year%E2%80%99s-eve-party-%E2%80%93-is-staged-for-last-time-162438144.html | title = On This Day: The Chelsea Arts Ball – London’s most ‘scandalous' New Year’s Eve Party – is staged for last time | last = Gavaghan | first = Julian | date = 30 December 2013 | website = Yahoo News | publisher = | access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.messynessychic.com/2014/12/30/the-chelsea-arts-ball-1947-the-most-scandalous-party-of-new-years-eve/ | title = The Chelsea Arts Ball, 1947: The Most Scandalous Party of New Year’s Eve | website = Messy Nessy Chic | access-date = 2016-02-25 }}</ref> Subsequently, private functions were held at the club instead, with similarly lavish decorations and themes.<ref name=":0" />
In 1966 the club was redecorated, a new bar was opened, and membership was opened to women artists.
[[File:Chelsea Arts Club - dazzle.jpg|thumb|The building painted with [[dazzle camouflage]]]] Although normally a plain white building, the club exterior is occasionally painted to coincide with a themed event. It has been painted by set designer Tony Common. In 2010 it was painted bright colours with images of circus performers, and in 2011 was painted to appear as if it had been bombed in order to coincide with celebrations marking 70 years since the end of [[The Blitz]].
==See also== * [[Gentlemen's club]] * [[List of London's gentlemen's clubs]]
==References== {{reflist}} * Anthony Lejeune, ''Gentlemen's Clubs of London'', London: Macdonald And Jane's, 1979 (ill. Malcolm Lewis). {{ISBN|0-8317-3800-6}}. * Tom Cross, ''Artists and Bohemians: 100 Years with the Chelsea Arts Club'', London: Quiller Press, 1992. {{ISBN|9781870948609}}.
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.chelseaartsclub.com}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fRsrUfkFZjA News footage of the 1922 new years ball] (British Pathe) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jAQ4Nis3Eyc News footage of the 1954 new years ball] (British Pathe) * [http://www.chelseaartsclub.com/proposal_form.pdf Membership proposal form]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}

{{Infobox museum | name = Color Factory | logo = File:Logo_of_Color_Factory.svg | logo_upright = 0.5 | logo_alt = Logo of Color Factory | logo_caption = | image = | map_type = | former_name = | established = August 2017 | location = [[San Francisco]], [[New York City]] | type = [[Pop-up exhibition]] | website = {{URL|https://colorfactory.co}} }}
'''Color Factory''' is a [[Pop-up exhibition|pop-up]] [[Interactive art|interactive]] [[art exhibition]] with brightly colored room-sized [[Installation art|installations]], each themed around the concept of [[color]]. It ran for eight and a half months in 2017 in [[San Francisco]], and, as of October 2018, is currently running in [[New York City]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jennawang/2018/09/29/the-rise-of-the-pop-up-economy|title=The Rise Of The Pop-Up Economy|last=Wang|first=Jenna|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2018/06/the-color-factory-new-york-city.html|title=The Ultimate Instagram Exhibit Is Headed to New York City|last=Bedolla|first=Daise|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/the-color-factory-experiential-art-exhibit-in-nyc-features-16-stunning-rooms-devoted-to-the-joy-of-color-10202362|title=The Instagram-Famous Color Factory Has 16 New Rooms With Built-In Cameras For Photo Opps|last=Lord|first=Emma|work=Bustle|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref>
Color Factory has commonly been cited as part of a trend of “Instagram museums”, temporary art exhibitions catered towards younger [[Millennials|millennial]] audiences which are designed to be [[Photograph|photographed]] (especially in [[Selfie|selfies]]) and shared on [[Instagram]] and other [[social media]].<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://gothamist.com/2018/07/19/color_factory_coming_to_instagram.php|title=Introducing Color Factory, The Latest Instagrammable Pop-Up Coming To NYC|work=Gothamist|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180719172436/http://gothamist.com/2018/07/19/color_factory_coming_to_instagram.php|archive-date=2018-07-19|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-color-factory-is-made-for-instagram-but-is-it-art|title=The Color Factory Is Made for Instagram, but Is It Art?|last=Winkelman|first=Natalia|date=2018-08-21|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/26/arts/color-factory-museum-of-ice-cream-rose-mansion-29rooms-candytopia.html|title=The Existential Void of the Pop-Up ‘Experience’|last=Hess|first=Amanda|date=2018-09-26|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/03/tech/instagram-pop-up-experiences-rose-mansion/index.html|title=Instagramable pop-ups can teach retailers a thing or two|last=Business|first=Story by Kaya Yurieff, CNN Business Video by Lisa Fischer, CNN|work=CNN|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Vox|title=How "Instagram traps" are changing art museums|date=2018-09-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qx_r-dP22Ps|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref> Co-founder Jordan Ferney has publicly pushed back against descriptions of Color Factory as an Instagram museum, stating that her goal “had always been to make something that was beautiful to experience, not photograph”.<ref name=":5" />
Artists whose works have been featured in Color Factory include [[Jason Polan]], Lakwena Maciver, Molly Young, Tosha Stimage, and Tom Stayte.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> Exhibits include [[Ball pit|ballpits]], [[balloon]]-filled rooms, and [[Illuminated dance floor|illuminated dance floors]], with cameras preinstalled throughout the exhibition for photography.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/color-factory-exhibition-museum-art-new-york-august-2018-Manhattan-Exhibition-488534541.html|title=Museum of Explosive Color Coming to NYC|work=NBC New York|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref>
== History == Color Factory was founded in August 2017 by event-planner/blogger Jordan Ferney, artist Leah Rosenberg, and designer Erin Jang.<ref name=":0" /> It originally debuted as a one-month, 15-installation, 12,000 ft<sup>2</sup> exhibition in San Francisco, sponsored by [[Alaskan Airlines]] and Method Soap.<ref name=":0" /> Due to its popularity (at one point causing its [[Eventbrite]] ticketing page to crash from high demand)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sf.curbed.com/2017/7/31/16069956/color-factory-sf-tickets|title=Peek inside San Francisco’s newest Instagramable hotspot|work=Curbed SF|access-date=2018-10-27}}</ref>, this San Francisco run was later extended to last for a total of eight and a half months.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":3" />
In June and July 2018, Color Factory partnered with the [[Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum]] in New York City to exhibit the “[[Manhattan]] Color Walk”, an outdoor art installation which painted the ground with several stripes of colors, each sampled from a different street of Manhattan.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Art-Piece-Expresses-Colors-From-All-Across-Manhattan.html|title=Walk Displays Colors from 265 Blocks of NYC|work=NBC New York|access-date=2018-10-27|language=en}}</ref>
In August 2018, Color Factory reopened as a temporary 16-installation, 20,000 ft<sup>2</sup> standalone exhibition in New York City's [[SoHo, Manhattan|SoHo]] neighborhood, sponsored by [[Maybelline]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== See Also ==
* [[Museum of Ice Cream]] *[[Museum of Pizza]]
== References == <references />
== External links ==
* {{Official website|http://colorfactory.co/}}
{{coord missing|California}}
[[Category:Art exhibitions]] [[Category:Museums in San Francisco]] [[Category:Museums in New York City]] [[Category:2017 establishments in California]]

'''Crunchiness''' is the sensation of muffled grinding of a foodstuff. Crunchiness differs from [[crispness]] in that a crisp item is quickly atomized, while a crunchy one offers sustained, [[granular]] resistance to [[jaw]] action. While crispness is difficult to maintain, crunchiness is difficult to overcome.
Crunchy foods are associated with freshness.<ref name=Roach />
==Relationship to sound== Crispness and crunchiness can each be "assessed on the basis of [[sound]] alone, on the basis of oral-tactile clues alone, or on the basis of a combination of auditory and oral-tactile information".<ref name=crunch>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTR7VEJPDWAC&pg=PA384&lpg=PA384&dq=crunchiness&source=web&ots=iUlXba5eN4&sig=r17PZ2f_wWPXBu_L2yigLsr9Z-M|title=Sensory Evaluation of Food: Principles and Practices}}</ref> An acoustic [[frequency]] of 1.9 kHz seems to mark the threshold between the two sensations, with crunchiness at frequencies below, and crispness at frequencies above.
Crunchy food breaks at speeds faster than the [[speed of sound]]. The sound of crunching food is therefore "a tiny [[sonic boom]]".<ref name=Roach>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/26/health/mary-roach-on-studying-food-and-how-humans-eat-it.html|title=Mary Roach on Studying How Humans Chew and Eat |last=Roach |first=Mary |date=26 March 2013 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=28 March 2013}}</ref>
==Examples== Crunchy foods include: *[[Carrot]]s *[[Crouton]]s *[[Nestlé Crunch]] *[[Mint (candy)|Mints]] *[[Potato chip]]s *[[Ice]]
==See also== *[[Chewiness]] *[[Mouthfeel]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Gustatory system]] [[Category:Gustation]]
{{food-stub}}

revision.comment: /* VisualIDs, semanticons, and identicons */ added wikilink
revision.text:
'''Distinguishable interfaces''' use computer graphic principles to automatically generate easily distinguishable appearance for computer data.
Although the [[desktop metaphor]] revolutionized user interfaces, there is evidence that a spatial layout alone does little to help in locating files and other data; distinguishable appearance is also required. Studies have shown that average users have considerable difficulty finding files on their personal computers, even ones that they created the same day.<ref>{{Citation | last = Barreau | first = Deborah | author2 = Bonnie A. Nardi | title = Finding and reminding: file organization from the desktop | journal = SIGCHI Bulletin | volume = 27 | number = 3 | pages = 647–656 | year = 1995 }}</ref> Search engines do not always help, since it has been found that users often know of the existence of a file without being able to specify relevant search terms. On the contrary, people appear to incrementally search for files using some form of context.<ref>{{Citation | last = Teevan | first = Jaime | author2 = Christine Alvarado | author3 = Mark S. Ackerman | author4 = David R. Karger | title = The Perfect Search Engine Is Not Enough: A Study of Orienteering Behavior in Directed Search | journal = CHI conference | year = 2004 }}</ref>
Recently researchers and web developers have argued that the problem is the lack of distinguishable appearance: in the traditional computer interface most objects and locations appear identical. This problem rarely occurs in the real world, where both objects and locations generally have easily distinguishable appearance. Discriminability was one of the recommendations in the ISO 9241-12 recommendation on presentation of information on visual displays (part of the overall report on [[ISO_9241|Ergonomics of Human System Interaction]]), however it was assumed in that report that this would be achieved by manual design of graphical symbols.
==VisualIDs, semanticons, and identicons== The mass availability of computer graphics supported the introduction of approaches that make better use of the brain's "visual hardware", by providing individual files and other abstract data with distinguishable appearance. This idea initially appeared in strictly academic VisualIDs<ref name="visualids"> {{Citation | last = Lewis | first = J.P. | author2 = Ruth Rosenholtz | author3 = Nickson Fong | author4 = Ulrich Neumann | title = VisualIDs: automatic distinctive icons for desktop interfaces | journal = ACM Transactions on Graphics | volume = 23 | number = 3 | year = 2004 }}</ref> and Semanticons<ref name="semanticons">{{Citation | last = Setlur | first = Vidya | author2 = Conrad Albrecht-Buehler | author3 = [[Amy Ashurst Gooch|Amy A. Gooch]] | author4 = Sam Rossoff | author5 = Bruce Gooch | title = Semanticons: Visual Metaphors as File Icons | journal = Computer Graphics Forum | volume = 24 | number = 3 | pages = 647–656 | year = 2005 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-8659.2005.00889.x}}</ref> works, but the web community has explored and rapidly adopted similar ideas, such as the [[Identicon]].
The VisualIDs project<ref name="visualids" /><ref>{{Cite web | last = Kanellos | first = Michael | title = Cnet News: Navigating PCs with pictures, not words | url=http://news.cnet.com/Navigating-PCs-with-pictures,-not-words/2100-1012_3-5395376.html | accessdate = 26 December 2010 }}</ref> automatically generated icons for files or other data based on a hash of the data identifier, so the icons had no relation to the content or meaning of the data. It was argued not only that generating meaningful icons is unnecessary<ref>{{Citation | last = Lewis | first = J.P. | title = VisualIDs: FAQ | url = http://scribblethink.org/Work/VisualIDs/visualids_faq.html#meaningful | accessdate = 19 March 2013 }}</ref> (their user study showed rapid learning of the arbitrary icons), but also that basing icons on ''content'' is actually ''incorrect''<ref>{{Citation | last = Lewis | first = J.P. | title = VisualIDs: FAQ | url = http://scribblethink.org/Work/VisualIDs/visualids_faq.html#autocontent | accessdate = 19 March 2013 }}</ref> ("contrasting visualization with visual identifiers"<ref name="visualids" />).
The Semanticons project<ref name="semanticons" /><ref>{{Cite web | last = Piquepaille | first = Roland | title = ZDNET: Semanticons reveal the meaning of files | url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/emergingtech/semanticons-reveal-the-meaning-of-files/116 | accessdate = 26 December 2010 }}</ref> developed by Setlur et al. demonstrated an algorithm to create icons that reflect the content of files. In this work the name, location and content of a file are parsed and used to retrieve related image(s) from an image database. These are then processed using a [[Non-photorealistic rendering]] technique in order to generate graphical icons.
Developer Don Park introduced the [[identicon]] library for making a visual icon from a hash of a data identifier. This initial public implementation has spawned a large number of implementations for various environments. In particular, identicons are now being used as default visual user identifiers (avatars) for several widely used systems. They are also used as a complement to [[Gravatar]]s, which are pre-existing avatar images created or chosen by users, instead of automatically generated images. (see [[#External links]]).
==Current research== While current web practice has followed the semantics-free approach of VisualIDs, recent research has followed the semantics-based approach of Semanticons. Examples include using data mining principles to automatically create "intelligent icons" that reflect the contents of files<ref>{{Citation | last = Keogh | first = Eamonn | author2 = Li Wei | author3 = Xiaopeng Xi | author4 = Stephano Lonardi | author5 = Jin Shieh | author6 = Scott Sirowy | title = Intelligent Icons: Integrating Lite-Weight Data Mining and Visualization into GUI Operating Systems | journal = ICDM | year = 2006 }}</ref> and creating icons for music files that reflect audio characteristics<ref>{{Citation | last = Kolhoff | first = Phillipp | author2 = Jacqueline Preuss | author3 = Jörn Lovisach | title = Content-based icons for music files | journal = Computers & Graphics | volume = 32 | number = 5 | year = 2008 }}</ref> or affective content.<ref>{{Citation | last = Kim | first = Hyun-Ju | author2 = Min-joon Yoo | author3 = Ji-yong Kwon | author4 = In-kwon Lee | title = Generating affective music icons in the emotion plane | journal = CHI conference | year = 2009 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Favicon]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.trnmag.com/Stories/2004/090804/Automatic_icons_organize_files_090804.html Technology Research News: Automatic icons organize files] * [http://www.hackerposse.com/~rozzin/VisualIDs/ libvisualid] Reference implementation of VisualIDs for Linux, by Joshua Judson Rosen. * [http://www.codinghorror.com/blog/2007/01/identicons-for-net.html Identicons for .NET] by Jeff Atwood and Jon Galloway * [http://sourceforge.net/projects/identicons/ PHP Identicons] * [http://scott.sherrillmix.com/blog/blogger/wp_identicon WP_Identicon] Identicon php plugin for Wordpress * [http://en.gravatar.com/site/implement/images/ gravitar.com] Gravitar.com's default image has an identicon option * [http://scribblethink.org/Work/VisualIDs/visualids.html VisualIDs: Scenery for Data Worlds] * [http://thenounproject.com The Noun Project]
[[Category:Communication design]] [[Category:Computer graphics]] [[Category:Web design]]

{{Infobox coat of arms |name = National Emblem of Afghanistan |image = National Emblem of Afghanistan 002.svg |image_width = 250 |middle = National Emblem of Afghanistan 001.svg |middle_width = 250 |middle_caption = Black and white version |lesser = |lesser_alt = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |armiger = [[Islamic Republic of Afghanistan]] |year_adopted = 2013 |crest = |torse = |shield = A [[mosque]] with a [[mihrab]] and [[minbar]] within, a representation of the [[Flag of Afghanistan|flag of Afghanistan]] on either side. |supporters = Two sheaves of wheat |compartment = |motto = {{lang|ar|لَا إِلٰهَ إِلَّا ٱلله مُحَمَّدٌ رَسُولُ ٱلله }}
([[shahadah]]) |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''National Emblem of [[Afghanistan]]''' has appeared in some form on the [[flag of Afghanistan]] since the beginning of the 20th century. The latest incarnation of the emblem has the inscription of the [[shahadah]] in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] at the top. Below it is the image of a [[mosque]] with a [[mihrab]] and [[minbar]], or pulpit, within.Constitution of Afghanistan, Article 19 http://www.afghanembassy.com.pl/afg/images/pliki/TheConstitution.pdf Attached to the mosque are two flags, taken to stand for flags of Afghanistan. Beneath the mosque is an inscription that states the name of the nation. Around the mosque are sheaves of wheat, and underneath that, the [[Hijri year]] 1298 (1919 in the Gregorian calendar), the year Afghanistan gained independence from the [[British Empire|British]] influence. == Historical == File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1901-1919).svg|[[Emirate of Afghanistan]] (1901–1919) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1919-1926).svg|Emirate of Afghanistan (1919–1926) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1926-1928).svg|[[Kingdom of Afghanistan]] (1926–1928) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1928-1929).svg|Kingdom of Afghanistan (1928–1929) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1929).svg|Kingdom of Afghanistan (1929) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1931-1973).svg|Kingdom of Afghanistan (1931–1973) File:Afghanistan arms 1973-1974.svg|[[Republic of Afghanistan]] (1973–1974) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1974-1978).svg|Republic of Afghanistan (1974–1978) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1978-1980).svg|[[Democratic Republic of Afghanistan]] (1978–1980) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1980-1987).svg| Democratic Republic of Afghanistan (1980–1987) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1987-1992).svg|Republic of Afghanistan (1987–1992) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (1992-1996).svg|[[Islamic State of Afghanistan]] (1992–2002, recognized by the [[United Nations|UN]]) File:Arms of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.svg|[[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan]] (1996–2001) File:Emblem of Afghanistan (2002-2004).svg|[[Transitional Islamic State of Afghanistan]] (2002–2004) File:Emblem of Afghanistan.svg|[[Islamic Republic of Afghanistan]] (2004–2013) == See also == *[[Flag of Afghanistan]] {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} '''English Touring Theatre''' (ETT) is a major [[touring theatre]] company based in [[London]], England.
==History== English Touring Theatre was founded in 1993 by [[Stephen Unwin (director)|Stephen Unwin]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Nuala Calvi |url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/16211/unwin-to-resign-as-english-touring-theatre |work=[[The Stage]]| title= Unwin to resign as English Touring Theatre director |date=14 March 2007 |accessdate=1 August 2012}}</ref> In 2008, the directorship of the company was taken over by Rachel Tackley, making ETT the first [[Theatrical producer|producer]]-led touring theatre company in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|author=Alistair Smith |url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/news/newsstory.php/17274/tackley-takes-on-english-touring-theatre |title=Tackley takes on English Touring Theatre |work= [[The Stage]] |date=26 June 2007 |accessdate=1 August 2012}}</ref> Richard Twyman succeeded Tackley to become the company's Artistic Director in November 2016.<ref name="Twyman">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-36596916 | title=Richard Twyman to succeed Rachel Tackley at English Touring Theatre | work=[[BBC News]] | date=22 June 2016 | accessdate=18 September 2016}}</ref>
==Awards== Awards for English Touring Theatre include:
'''2016''' * ''Theatre Awards UK ''Best Touring Production – for ''[[The Herbal Bed]]''<ref>{{cite web | url=https://uktheatre.org/theatre-industry/news/uk-theatre-awards-2016-winners// | title=Past Awards & Winners | publisher=UK Theatre | accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> '''2015''' * ''Theatre Awards UK ''Best Touring Production – for ''[[Twelfth Night]]''<ref name="Winners">{{cite web | url=http://uktheatre.org/training-events/uk-theatre-awards/past-awards-winners/ | title=Past Awards & Winners | publisher=UK Theatre | accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> '''2014''' * ''Theatre Awards UK ''Best Touring Production – for ''[[Translations]]''<ref name="Winners"/> '''2012''' * ''Theatre Awards UK ''Best Touring Production – for ''[[Anne Boleyn (play)|Anne Boleyn]]''<ref name="Theatre Awards UK">{{cite web|url=http://www.wyp.org.uk/news-stories/the-go-between-wins-at-theatre-awards-uk/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20150313060516/http://www.wyp.org.uk/news-stories/the-go-between-wins-at-theatre-awards-uk/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-03-13 |title=Theatre Awards UK |publisher=[[West Yorkshire Playhouse]] |date=2012 |accessdate=12 March 2015 }}</ref> '''2011''' * ''The Public Reviews'' Best of 2011 Award (joint) – for ''Tartuffe''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thepublicreviews.com/feature-the-public-reviews-best-of-2011/ |title=FEATURE: The Public Reviews’ best of 2011 |publisher=The Public Reviews |date=4 January 2012 |accessdate=1 August 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112035600/http://www.thepublicreviews.com/feature-the-public-reviews-best-of-2011/ |archive-date=12 January 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * ''[[The Stage]]'' 100 Awards – Best Producer<ref>{{cite web|author=The Stage 100 Awards – winners |url=http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/newsblog/2011/01/the-stage-100-awards---winners/ |work=[[The Stage]] |title=The Stage 100 Awards – winners |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616185102/http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/newsblog/2011/01/the-stage-100-awards---winners/ |archivedate=16 June 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> * ''[[Critics' Awards for Theatre in Scotland]]'' Best New Play – for ''The Three Musketeers and the Princess of Spain''<ref name="theatrescotland1">{{cite web|url=http://www.criticsawards.theatrescotland.com/Winners/10-11.html |title=CATS: 2010–11 winners |publisher=Criticsawards.theatrescotland.com |date= |accessdate=1 August 2012}}</ref> * ''Critics' Awards for Theatre in Scotland'' Best Ensemble – for ''The Three Musketeers and the Princess of Spain''<ref name="theatrescotland1"/> '''2010''' * ''Theatre Awards UK ''Renee Stepham Award for Best Presentation of Touring Theatre
==Productions== * ''The Weir'' (2017) * ''Rules For Living'' (2017) * ''Othello'' (2017) * ''William Wordsworth'' (2017) * ''Nell Gwynn'' (2017) * ''Silver Lining'' (2017) * ''Hamlet'' (2016) * ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' (2016) * ''[[French Without Tears (play)|French Without Tears]]'' (2016) * ''Brideshead Revisited'' adapted by [[Bryony Lavery]] in the first large-scale stage adaptation of [[Brideshead Revisited|the novel by Evelyn Waugh]] (2016) * ''[[The Herbal Bed]]'' (2016) * ''The Odyssey: Missing, Presumed Dead'' (2015) * ''[[A Mad World, My Masters]]'' (2015) * ''Arcadia'' (2015) * (with [[Sheffield Theatres]]) ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' by [[William Shakespeare]] (2014). Directed by [[Jonathan Munby]], designed by Colin Richmond.<ref name="Weleminsky-Smith">{{cite web | url=http://www.ayoungertheatre.com/review-twelfth-night-richmond-theatre-english-touring-theatre/ | title=Review: Twelfth Night, Richmond Theatre | publisher=A Younger Theatre | work=Reviews | date=21 November 2014 | accessdate=28 November 2014 | author=Alice Weleminsky-Smith}}</ref> Toured to: Sheffield Theatres; [[Grand Theatre, Blackpool]]; [[Watford Palace Theatre]]; [[Cambridge Arts Theatre]]; [[Hall for Cornwall]], [[Truro]]; [[Richmond Theatre]], [[Richmond, London]]; and [[Theatre Royal, Brighton]]<ref name="Twelfth">{{cite web | url=http://www.ett.org.uk/productions/81/twelfth-night | title=Twelfth Night | publisher=English Touring Theatre | work=Productions | date=2014 | accessdate=28 November 2014}}</ref> * ''[[The Misanthrope]]'' by [[Roger McGough]] after [[Moliere]] (2013).<ref name="Norman">{{Cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/theatre/389497/The-Misanthrope-review-English-Touring-Theatre-Richmond-Threatre |title=The Misanthrope review, English Touring Theatre, Richmond Threatre [sic] |last=Norman |first=Neil |date=5 April 2013 |work=[[Daily Express]] |accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref> Directed by Gemma Bodinetz. Toured to Liverpool Playhouse, Cambridge Arts Theatre, Richmond Theatre, Oxford Playhouse, [[Hall for Cornwall]]([[Truro]]), Northcott Theatre ([[Exeter]]), Theatre Royal Brighton, Nuffield Theatre ([[Southampton]]), The New Wolsey ([[Ipswich]]), York Theatre Royal and Theatre Royal Bath<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ett.org.uk/productions/74/the-misanthrope |title=The Misanthrope |date=2013 |access-date=9 August 2016 |website=English Touring Theatre}}</ref> * ''[[The Sacred Flame (play)|The Sacred Flame]]'' by [[W. Somerset Maugham]] (2012). Directed by Matthew Dunster. Toured to: [[Rose Theatre, Kingston]]; [[Northern Stage, Newcastle upon Tyne]]; [[Oxford Playhouse]]; [[New Wolsey Theatre]]; [[Liverpool Playhouse]]; [[Yvonne Arnaud Theatre]], Guildford; Theatre Royal, Brighton; [[University of Southampton#Arts|The Nuffield Theatre Southampton]]; and Cambridge Arts Theatre<ref name="The Sacred Flame">{{Cite web |url=http://www.ett.org.uk/productions/73/the-sacred-flame |title=The Sacred Flame |date=2012 |access-date=9 August 2016 |website=English Touring Theatre}}</ref> * ''[[The Real Thing (play)]]'' (2012) * ''Anne Boleyn'' (2012) * ''[[Tartuffe]]'' (2011) * ''Hundreds and Thousands'' (2011) * ''[[Eden End]]'' (2011) * ''Little Baby Jesus'' (2011) * ''Great Expectations'' (2011) * ''The Three Musketeers and the Princess of Spain'' (2010) * ''Lovesong'' (2010) * ''Marine Parade'' (2010) * ''Canary'' (2010) * ''Rum and Coca Cola'' (2010) * ''[[The Imaginary Invalid|The Hypochondriac]]'' (2009) * ''Been So Long'' (2009) * ''The Grapes of Wrath'' (2009) * ''Where There's a Will'' (2009) * ''[[Entertaining Mr Sloane]]'' (2009) * ''Far From the Madding Crowd'' (2008) * ''Hello and Goodbye'' (2008) * ''[[Uncle Vanya]]'' (2007) * ''[[The Changeling (play)|The Changeling]]'' (2007) * ''Someone Else's Shoes'' (2007) * ''[[French Without Tears (play)|French Without Tears]]'' (2007) * ''[[Mother Courage and Her Children]]'' (2006) * ''The Old Country'' (2006) * ''[[Hamlet]]'' (2005) * ''[[Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead]]'' (2005) * ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' (2004) * ''[[Honeymoon Suite]]'' (2004) * ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' (2003) * ''Anton Chekhov'' (2003) * ''John Gabriel Borkman'' (2003) * ''The Boy Who Fell into a Book'' (2002)<ref>{{cite web|title=The Boy Who Fell Into A Book|publisher= Sophie Hunter Central|url=http://sophiehunter.net/post/125168284650/the-boy-who-fell-into-a-book-2002-play|date= 27 July 2015|accessdate= 9 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ETT Productions|url=http://www.ett.org.uk/productions/41/the-boy-who-fell-into-a-book|website=English Touring Theatre}}</ref> * ''[[King Lear]]'' (2002) * ''Ghosts'' (2002) * ''[[The York Realist]]'' (2001) * ''The Caretaker'' (2001) * ''Fool for Love'' (2001) * ''[[The Cherry Orchard]]'' (2000) * ''The Master Builder'' (1999) * ''Don Juan'' (1999) * ''Hushabye Mountain'' (1999) * ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'' (1998) * ''A Difficult Age'' (1998) * ''Shellfish'' (1998) * ''[[Measure for Measure]]'' (1997) * ''[[The Seagull]]'' (1997) * ''Design for Living'' (1997) * ''[[Henry IV Part I|Henry IV Parts I]] and [[Henry IV Part II|II]]'' (1996) * ''The School for Scandal'' (1996) * ''Hedda Gabler'' (1996) * ''Rupert Street Lonely Hearts Club'' (1995) * ''[[Macbeth]]'' (1995) * ''[[The Importance of Being Earnest]]'' (1995) * ''[[The School for Wives]]'' (1995) * ''No Man's Land'' (1994) * ''[[As You Like It]]'' (1994) * ''[[The Beaux' Stratagem]]'' (1994) * ''[[A Doll's House]]'' (1994) * ''[[A Taste of Honey]]'' (1993) * ''[[Hamlet]]'' (1993) * ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' (1993)
==Digital Theatre== ETT was one of the organisations which collaborated in the launch of [[Digital Theatre]], a project of recording and distributing theatre performance digitally. The first performance filmed and released was ''Far From the Madding Crowd''.<ref>{{cite web| last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Leading theatres launch downloadable shows| work = | publisher = Official London Theatre Guide| date = | url = http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/latest/view/item107946/&t=Leading%20theatres%20launch%20downloadable%20shows/| doi = | accessdate =15 February 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ett.org.uk/ ETT homepage]

revision.text:
{{About|the painting by Nicolas Poussin|the painting by Guercino|Et in Arcadia ego (Guercino)}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Nicolas Poussin - Et in Arcadia ego (deuxième version).jpg | title=Et in Arcadia ego | other_title_1=Les Bergers d'Arcadie | artist=Nicolas Poussin| year=1637–1638 | medium=oil on canvas | height_metric=87 | width_metric=120 | height_imperial= 34.25 | width_imperial = 47.24 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum=Musée du Louvre }} '''''Et in Arcadia ego''''' (also known as '''''Les bergers d'Arcadie''''' or '''''The Arcadian Shepherds''''')<ref>Braider, Christopher, ''Refiguring the Real: Picture and Modernity in Word and Image, 1400–1700'', p. 292, 2015, Princeton University Press, {{ISBN|1400872758}}, 9781400872756</ref> is a 1637–38 painting by the leading painter of the classical [[17th-century French art|French Baroque]] style, [[Nicolas Poussin]] (1594–1665). It depicts a [[pastoral]] scene with idealized [[shepherd]]s from [[classical antiquity]] clustering around an austere [[tomb]]. It is held in the [[Louvre]], [[Paris]].
Poussin painted two versions of the subject under the same title; his earlier version, painted in 1627, is held at [[Chatsworth House]]. An earlier treatment of the theme was painted by [[Guercino]] circa 1618–22, also titled ''[[Et in Arcadia ego (Guercino)|Et in Arcadia ego]]''.
==Title== The translation of the phrase is "Even in Arcadia, there am I". The usual interpretation is that "I" refers to [[Death (personification)|Death]], and "Arcadia" means a utopian land. It would thus be a ''[[memento mori]]''. During Antiquity, many Greeks lived in cities close to the sea, and led an urban life. Only [[Arcadia (ancient region)|Arcadians]], in the middle of the [[Peloponnese]], lacked cities, were far from the sea, and led a shepherd life. Thus Arcadia symbolized pure, rural, idyllic life, far from the city.<ref>{{etymonline|Arcadia}}</ref>
However, Poussin's biographer, [[André Félibien]], interpreted the phrase to mean that "the person buried in this tomb lived in Arcadia"; in other words, that the person too once enjoyed the pleasures of life on earth. This reading was common in the 18th and 19th centuries. For example, [[William Hazlitt]] wrote that Poussin "describes some shepherds wandering out in a morning of the spring, and coming to a tomb with this inscription, 'I also was an Arcadian'."<ref>{{cite book|title=The round table: a collection of essays on literature, men, and manners, by William Hazlitt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7HYPAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA252&dq=hazlitt+%22round+table%22+%22why+the+arts+are+not+progressive%22&cad=4#v=onepage&q&f=false|chapter=Why the arts are not progressive – A fragment|year=1817|page=258|publisher=Constable|location=Edinburgh and London}}</ref>
The former interpretation ("ego" referring to Death) is now generally considered more likely; the ambiguity of the phrase is the subject of a famous essay by the [[art historian]] [[Erwin Panofsky]] (see References). Either way, the sentiment was meant to set up an [[irony|ironic]] contrast between the shadow of death and the usual idle merriment that the [[nymph]]s and swains of ancient Arcadia were thought to embody.
==Inspiration== [[Image:Et-in-Arcadia-ego.jpg|thumb|[[Et in Arcadia ego (Guercino)|Guercino's version]] of the subject.]] The first appearance of a tomb with a memorial inscription (to [[Daphnis]]) amid the idyllic settings of Arcadia appears in [[Virgil]]'s ''[[Eclogues]]'' V 42 ff. Virgil took the idealized Sicilian rustics that had first appeared in the ''Idylls'' of [[Theocritus]] and set them in the primitive Greek district of Arcadia (see Eclogues VII and X). The idea was taken up anew in the circle of [[Lorenzo de' Medici]] in the 1460s and 1470s, during the [[Florentine Renaissance]].
In his pastoral work ''Arcadia'' (1504), [[Jacopo Sannazaro]] fixed the Early Modern perception of Arcadia as a lost world of [[idyll]]ic bliss, remembered in regretful dirges. The first pictorial representation of the familiar ''memento mori'' theme that was popularized in 16th-century Venice, now made more concrete and vivid by the inscription <small>ET IN ARCADIA EGO</small>, is [[Et in Arcadia ego (Guercino)|Guercino]]'s version, painted between 1618 and 1622 (in the [[Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica]], Rome), in which the inscription gains force from the prominent presence of a [[Skull (mythology)|skull]] in the foreground, beneath which the words are carved.
==1627 version== [[Image:Poussin1627.jpg|thumb|[[Nicolas Poussin|Poussin's]] 1627 version of the ''Arcadian Shepherds'', in [[Chatsworth House]], depicting a different tomb with the same inscription.]] Poussin's own first version of the painting (now in [[Chatsworth House]]) was probably commissioned as a reworking of Guercino's version. It is in a far more [[Baroque]] style than the later version, characteristic of Poussin's early work. In the Chatsworth painting the shepherds are actively discovering the half-hidden and overgrown tomb, and are reading the inscription with curious expressions. The shepherdess, standing at the left, is posed in sexually suggestive fashion, very different from her austere counterpart in the later version. The later version has a far more geometric composition and the figures are much more contemplative. The mask-like face of the shepherdess conforms to the conventions of the Classical "Greek profile".
==Interpretation== {{more citations needed|date=January 2017}} The most important difference between the two versions is that in the latter version, one of the two shepherds recognizes the shadow of his companion on the tomb and circumscribes the silhouette with his finger. According to an ancient tradition (see [[Pliny the Elder]], ''[[Natural History (Pliny)|Natural History]]'' XXXV 5, 15), this is the moment in which the art of painting is first discovered. Thus, the shepherd's shadow is the first image in art history. But the shadow on the tomb is also a symbol of death (in the first version symbolized by a skull on the top of the tomb). The meaning of this highly intricate composition seems to be that, from prehistory onward, the discovery of art has been the creative response of humankind to the shocking fact of mortality. Thus, death’s claim to rule even Arcadia is challenged by art (symbolized by the beautifully dressed maiden), who must insist that she was discovered in Arcadia too, and that she is the legitimate ruler everywhere, whilst death only usurps its power. In the face of death, art's duty—indeed, her ''raison d’être''—is to recall absent loved ones, console anxieties, evoke and reconcile conflicting emotions, surmount isolation, and facilitate the expression of the unutterable.<ref>Cf. Becht-Jördens, Gereon; Wehmeier, Peter M. (2003). Picasso und die christliche Ikonographie. Dietrich Reimer Verlag, Berlin. pp. 181–209</ref>
==Sculpted versions== [[Image:Shugborough arcadia.jpg|thumb|The Shugborough relief, adapted from an engraving of Poussin's second version.]]
The undated mid-eighteenth-century marble bas-relief is part of the Shepherds Monument, a garden feature at [[Shugborough House]], Staffordshire, England. Beneath it is the cryptic [[Shugborough inscription]], as yet undeciphered.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shugborough.org.uk/AcademyShepherdsMon-169 |title=The Shepherd's Monument |publisher=Shugborough |accessdate=2011-07-26}}</ref> The reversed composition suggests that it was copied from an [[engraving]], the compositions of which are commonly reversed because direct copies to the plate produce mirror images on printing.
In 1832 another relief was sculpted as part of the monument marking Poussin's tomb in Rome, on which it appears beneath a bust of the artist.<ref>http://www.duepassinelmistero.com/_borders/POUSSIN_3.jpg</ref> In the words of the art historian Richard Verdi, it appears as if the shepherds are contemplating "their own author's death."<ref>Warwick, G. & Scott, K., [http://assets.cambridge.org/052164/0040/sample/0521640040WSC00.pdf ''Commemorating Poussin: Reception and Interpretation of the Artist''], [[Cambridge University Press]], 1999. Cf. "Introduction: Commemorating Poussin" by Katie Scott, p. 9. "As Richard Verdi has noted, this change of context resulted in Poussin's shepherds being led to contemplate their own author's death, and invited the viewer to ponder the monument with the same solemnity and poignancy with which the shepherds brood on Death's incursion into Arcadia." * Also cf. Verdi, Richard, "Poussin's giants: from romanticism to surrealism", in this collection.</ref>
==References in other works== {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | video1 =[http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/Poussin-Et-in-Arcadia-Ego.html Nicolas Poussin's ''Et in Arcadia Ego''], [[Smarthistory]] }} * ''Et in Arcadia ego'' (the German ''Auch ich in Arkadien!'' is used) is the motto of ''[[Italian Journey]]'' (1816–17) by [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]].<ref>Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, [http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/2404/pg2404.html ''Italienische Reise''], www.gutenberg.org. Retrieved 24 October 2012.</ref> * ''Et in Arcadia ego'' is the title of section 295, Volume II, Part Two ("The Wanderer and his Shadow"), of [[Friedrich Nietzsche]]'s ''[[Human, All Too Human]]'' (1880). The passage describes a pastoral evening scene in the high mountains, finishing with the lines: "Unconsciously, as if nothing could be more natural, you peopled this pure, clear world of light (which had no trace of yearning, of expectancy, of looking forward or backward) with Greek heroes. You felt it all as Poussin and his school felt it, at once heroic and idyllic. So individual men too have lived, constantly feeling themselves in the world and the world in themselves, and among them one of the greatest men, the inventor of a heroico-idyllic form of philosophy, Epicurus."<ref>Friedrich Nietzsche, [https://archive.org/stream/humanalltoohuman033142mbp/humanalltoohuman033142mbp_djvu.txt ''Human, All Too Human''], archive.org. Retrieved 24 October 2012.</ref> *''I Too Lived in Arcadia'' is the title of the 1942 memoirs of [[Marie Adelaide Belloc Lowndes]], describing the life of her mother, the English feminist [[Bessie Rayner Parkes]] *''Et in Arcadia Ego'' is the title of Book One of [[Evelyn Waugh]]'s ''[[Brideshead Revisited]]'' (1945) in which a skull bearing the phrase acts as a metaphor for death and for a yearning for a lost paradise resulting from the transformation of war.<ref name="Stevenson1993">{{cite book|last=Stevenson|first=Randall|title=A Reader's Guide to the Twentieth-century Novel in Britain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ul-8hrkUzR4C&lpg=PA87&pg=PA87#v=snippet&q=%22Et%20in%20Arcadia%20Ego%22|accessdate=2 September 2014|year=1993|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|isbn=0-8131-0823-3|pages=87–}}</ref> *''Et in Arcadia Ego'' is the title of a dystopian poem published by [[W. H. Auden]] in 1965.<ref name="Auden1965">{{cite journal|last=Auden|first=W.H.|title=Et in Arcadia Ego|journal=The New York Review of Books|date=1965-06-03|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1965/jun/03/et-in-arcadia-ego/}}</ref> *In conjunction with John Andrew, the artist [[Ian Hamilton Finlay]] created a marble carving entitled ''Et in Arcadia ego'' in 1976. The main part of the carving shows a military tank in a pastoral landscape, below which are carved the title and the words "After Nicholas Poussin". Several other works by Finlay directly or indirectly reference Poussin's artwork.<ref name=Abrioux1985>{{Citation|pages=205–207|title=Ian Hamilton Finlay: A Visual Primer|last1=Abrioux|first1=Yves|publisher=Reaktion Books|year=1985|ISBN=0-948462-00-0}}</ref> *The authors of the pseudohistory ''[[The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail]]'' (1982), under the false impression that "et in arcadia ego" was not a proper Latin sentence, proposed that it is an [[anagram]] for ''I! Tego arcana dei'', which translates to "Begone! I keep God's secrets", suggesting that the tomb contains the remains of [[Jesus]] or another important [[Bible|Biblical]] figure. *Poussin's 'Et In Arcadia Ego' features prominently in the [[Jane Jensen]] video game [[Gabriel Knight 3: Blood of the Sacred, Blood of the Damned.]] The paintings alleged mystical symbolism and occult imagery is used to help create a story based on the idea that the tomb of Christ is located in the south of France. *The phrase appears in [[Cormac McCarthy]]'s novel ''[[Blood Meridian]]'' (1985) when the character Tobin informs The Kid that the phrase is the name [[Judge Holden]] has ascribed to his rifle, noting "A reference to the lethal in it."<ref>McCarthy, Cormac. ''Blood Meridian, or, The Evening Redness In The West'' (New York: Random House, 1985; London: Picador, 1989).</ref> *[[Arcadia (band)|Arcadia]] was the name of [[Duran Duran]]'s spin off band formed in 1985 by Simon Le Bon, Nick Rhodes and Roger Taylor, reportedly because of the inscription on this painting.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/artists/0f4e6cc8-8a38-4741-b344-9d388def0060 |title=Music – Arcadia |publisher=BBC |date=2009-03-15 |accessdate=2011-07-26}}</ref> *''Et in Arcadia ego'' was the [[Arcadia (play)#Title|originally planned title]] of [[Tom Stoppard]]'s 1993 play, ''[[Arcadia (play)|Arcadia]]'', in which the phrase is used erroneously by one character (whose misuse is acknowledged by two other characters). The phrase also reflects the themes of the play itself.<ref>Fleming, Tom. ''Stoppard's "Arcadia"'' (Modern Theatre Guides, London: Continuum). {{ISBN|978-0-8264-9621-8}}.</ref> *The fourth movement from [[Thomas Adès]]' 1994 string quartet ''[[Arcadiana]]'' is called 'Et ... (tango mortale)' *In ''[[Earthquake Weather (novel)|Earthquake Weather]]'' (1997) by [[Tim Powers]], the phrase, interpreted as an unfinished sentence meaning "Even in Arcadia, I...", plays a recurring role, tied into the book's themes of the [[Fisher King]] and [[Dionysus]] in his role as a [[psychopomp]]. *''Et in Arcadia Ego'' is the title of a closing chapter in [[Jesse Bullington]]'s historical fantasy novel ''[[The Enterprise of Death]]'' (2001). *[[Ben Okri]]'s ''[[In Arcadia]]'' (2002) follows a filmcrew shooting a documentary about Poussin's painting.<ref>Okri, Ben. ''In Arcadia'' (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, London, 2002). {{ISBN|978-0-297-82960-7}}.</ref>
==See also== * [[Et in Arcadia ego (Guercino)|''Et in Arcadia ego'' (Guercino)]]

{{Infobox animanga/Header | name = Game Center Arashi | image = Game Center Arashi manga vol 1 reprint.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = Cover of the 2000 reprint of first manga volume | ja_kanji = ゲームセンターあらし | ja_romaji = Geimu Sentā Arashi | genre = [[Action genre|Action]] }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | author = [[Mitsuru Sugaya]] | publisher = [[Shogakukan]] | demographic = [[Children's anime and manga|Children]], [[Shōnen manga|Shōnen]] | magazine = [[CoroCoro Comic]] | first = 1978 | last = 1984 | volumes = 17 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = tv series | director = Tameo Ogawa | producer = | writer = Haruya Yamazaki
[[Sōji Yoshikawa]]
Toyohiro Andō | music = [[Kōji Makaino]] | studio = [[Shin-Ei Animation]] | network = [[Nippon Television|NTV]] | first = April 5, 1982 | last = September 27, 1982 | episodes = 26 | episode_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''Game Center Arashi'''''|ゲームセンターあらし|Geimu Sentā Arashi}} is a Japanese [[manga]] by [[Mitsuru Sugaya]], which ran in ''[[CoroCoro Comic]]'' from 1978 to 1984. It sold over 5 million copies {{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} and won the 1983 [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for [[children's manga]].{{cite web|url=http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |script-title=ja:小学館漫画賞: 歴代受賞者 |publisher=Shogakukan |language=Japanese |accessdate=2007-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929094941/http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }} The series was adapted as a popular [[anime]] television show that aired in 1982 in [[Japan]] on Mondays from 7:00pm to 7:30pm.; and in [[Hong Kong]]. In Japanese, the word "Arashi" means "storm". In [[Hong Kong]], the show aired under the title 電子神童, which translates to "Electronic Prodigy". The series was considered [[Cultural icon|iconic]] in [[Asia]] {{Citation needed|date=August 2007}}, since it came at a time when the public was being exposed to [[video games]] for the first time. The [[manga]] and TV series opened the imagination and possibilities of what gaming entertainment was about, while boosting its popularity as a new [[phenomenon]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} ==Story== The story is about a young boy named Arashi Ishino who is obsessed with video games. He would spend all his time trying to beat the games and conquer the local [[Arcade game|arcades]]. He would meet competitors like Satoru Daimonji and Ishii, who would try to out match him with higher scores. At a certain point in each episode, he would display his special skill of unleashing a [[top]] which will spin so fast that both the top and his hands would catch on fire. On release, the spin would land on or near the [[Arcade cabinet|cabinet]] panels, turning the ordinary button into a [[turbo button]] thus giving him a major advantage. His appearance is known for being bucktoothed, and he always wears a hat labeled "Arashi" with a picture of a [[Sprite (computer graphics)|sprited]] alien. ''Game Center Arashi'' was the first animation with a [[gamer]] as the lead character and have the plot revolve around life with competitive gaming. Some of the games featured in the show include [[Space Invaders]], [[Breakout (arcade game)|Breakout]], [[Galaxian]], though they were not explicitly named. Some of Arashi's gaming techniques even have special names like "Blazed Top", "Vacuum Hurricane Shot", "Fish Stance".Clements, Jonathan. McCarthy Helen. [2006] (2006). The Anime Encyclopedia: Revised & Expanded Edition. Berkeley, CA: Stone Bridge Press. {{ISBN|978-1-933330-10-5}} ==Characters== ;{{nihongo|Arashi Ishino|石野あらし|Ishino Arashi}} {{Voiced by|[[Satomi Majima]]}} ;{{nihongo|Satoru Daimonji|大文字さとる|Daimonji Satoru}} {{Voiced by|[[Eiko Hisamura]]}} ;{{nihongo|Ippeita Tsukikage|月影一平太|Tsukikage Ippeita}} {{Voiced by|[[Kenichi Ogata (voice actor)|Kenichi Ogata]]}} ==Anime== ===Staff=== {|class="wikitable" ! Arashi's enemy is Arashi?! |- |} ==Additional versions and appearances== {{Refimprove section|date=December 2010}} In 1999, the series spawned a [[PlayStation]] [[novel]] called [[Game Center Arashi R]]. In 2004 [[Microsoft]] [[Tokyo]] used the character of Arashi as a mascot to boost [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] sales and image. While the 2002 manga [[Arcade Gamer Fubuki]] reused the concept of a powerful gamer in the arcades, and also spawned a TV series of the same name, that show used entirely different characters and plots, modernizing while separating itself from the 1982 counterpart. In 2006 the Let's TV Play Classic series of Plug and Plays used Arashi as a mascot. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.m-sugaya.com/arashi/index2.htm Official site] *[http://www.dyrell.net/comic/arashi/ Game Center Arashi Manga info] *{{Ann|anime|2206}} *[http://www.gamespot.com/news/2004/09/17/news_6107746.html Arashi reborn for Xbox] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061104222847/http://www.m-sugaya.com/eng/index.htm Author] {{Shogakukan Manga Award - Children}} {{Shin-Ei Animation}} [[Category:1978 manga]] [[Category:1982 anime television series]] [[Category:Anime series based on manga]] [[Category:CoroCoro Comic]] [[Category:Nippon Television shows]] [[Category:Shōnen manga]] [[Category:Shin-Ei Animation]] [[Category:Shogakukan manga]] [[Category:Shogakukan franchises]] [[Category:Shōnen manga]] [[Category:Winners of the Shogakukan Manga Award for children's manga]] [[Category:Works about video games]]
